title: Max Newman
summary: Maxwell Herman Alexander Newman, FRS,[3] (7 February 1897 â€“ 22 February 1984), generally known as Max Newman, was a British mathematician and codebreaker. His work in World War II led to the construction of Colossus,[7] the world's first operational, programmable electronic computer, and he established the Royal Society Computing Machine Laboratory at the University of Manchester, which produced the world's first working, stored-program electronic computer in 1948, the Manchester Baby.[8][9][10][11][12]
